tossups.question: A legend about this dynasty’s ancestor claims that he was sort of kidnapped and forced to be the imam of Tafilat by a group of locals who were convinced that his holy blood would give them better crops. A ruler from this dynasty would apocryphally whip out his pistol and execute servants for insufficiently twirling a parasol, but otherwise relied heavily on a slave force of sub-Saharan Africans called the Black Guard. That ruler from this dynasty stripped the once-majestic El Badi palace for spare parts as an added insult to their predecessors; those predecessors built the complex with ransom money after killing Thomas Stucley and (*) Sebastian I at the battle of Alcacer Quibir. Moulay Ismail ruled this dynasty, whose king Mohammed III made it the first foreign state to recognize the U.S. as a nation. Serial child-rapist Daniel Galvan was pardoned by the current ruler of this dynasty, Mohammed VI. For 10 points, name this dynasty that has led Morocco since 1659, whose name is phonetically equivalent to the ruling dynasty of Syria?
tossups.answer: Alaouite Dynasty [or Alawite Dynasty] <History - Other/World>
tossups.answer_formatted: Alaouite Dynasty <History - Other/World> [or Alawite Dynasty]

tossups.question: At the end of a novel by this author, a character drops dead after betting he can match his ancestor’s feat of filling a drinking horn with whiskey punch and swallowing it in one gulp. This author’s frequent correspondence with Rachel Mordecai Lazarus motivated her to attack anti-Semitism in her novel Harrington. Almost all of this author’s books were written under the supervision of her domineering father, Richard Lovell. She contrasted the rise of the narrator’s ambitious son Jason with the downfall of the title (*) location in the first “Big House” novel. Published in 1800, that novel by this author traces the reckless mismanagement of Sir Patrick, Sir Murtaugh, Sir Kit, and Sir Condy, and is narrated by the steward Thady Quirk. For 10 points, name this author who attacked exploitative Anglo-Irish landlords in her novels The Absentee and Castle Rackrent.
tossups.answer: Maria Edgeworth <Literature - British>
tossups.answer_formatted: Maria Edgeworth <Literature - British>

tossups.question: The image of “coins which have lost their embossing” is used in this work to describe a “sum of human relations which have been poetically and rhetorically intensified.” This essay asserts that there is “little to praise” when someone hides something behind a bush, then looks for it in the same place and finds it there. This essay notes that the “fundamental human drive” is the drive toward the formation of metaphors. This essay opens by claiming that the “most arrogant and mendacious minute of world history” was the invention of (*) knowledge. It claims that the thing-in-itself would be “incomprehensible” and undesirable to the creators of language, and also examines the meanings of “leaf” and “honesty” after asserting that “every word instantly becomes a concept.” For 10 points, name this Friedrich Nietzsche essay about the epistemological nature of veracity and deception.
tossups.answer: “On Truth and Lies in a Nonmoral Sense” [or “On Truth and Lies in an Extra-Moral Sense”; or “Über Wahrheit und Lüge im aussermoralischen Sinne”; accept answers swapping Lie for “Lies”] <Philosophy>
tossups.answer_formatted: “On Truth and Lies in a Nonmoral Sense” <Philosophy> [or On Truth or Lies in an Extra-Moral Sense; or Über Wahrheit und Lüge im aussermoralischen Sinne; accept answers swapping Lie for “Lies]
acceptable: “On Truth and Lies in a Nonmoral Sense” <Philosophy>
“On Truth and Lies in a Nonmoral Sense” <Philosophy>
Über Wahrheit und Lüge im aussermoralischen Sinne

tossups.question: An anomalous transfer of spectral weight in these materials can be seen in their photoemission spectroscopy. Confining a Bose–Einstein condensate in an optical lattice produces examples of these materials that lack coherence. As the potential depth of that lattice is decreased, the condensate transitions from one of these materials into a superfluid. The transition into these materials occurs when the density of electrons to the one-third power times the Bohr radius is greater than a critical value. They can be identified by the presence of a (*) second change in the Hall coefficient’s sign during doping, which is part of a general property that is found alongside antiferromagnetic order. These materials, which include vanadium (III) oxide and nickel oxide, are accurately described by the Hubbard model in the limit where the transfer integral of a single electron is overwhelmed by an on-site Coulombic interaction term. For 10 points, name these materials in which electron-electron repulsion prevents conductivity.
tossups.answer: Mott insulator [prompt on partial answer] <Science - Physics>
tossups.answer_formatted: Mott insulator <Science - Physics> [prompt on partial answer]

tossups.question: A coup launched during and sometimes named for this month was recorded by audio technicians in the “Night of the Transistor Radios.” During that coup during this month, Antonio Tejero staged a coup to attempt to overthrow Juan Carlos I by taking parliament at gunpoint. Lin Biao was named Mao’s successor in part for his sweeping condemnation of a resistance movement to the Cultural Revolution known as the (*) “Countercurrent” of this month. Anger over the Stavisky Affair led to spontaneous right-wing riots in Paris in 1934 named for the 6th of this month. Klement Gottwald overthrew the government of Edvard Benes in this month, securing Communist rule in Czechoslovakia in a coup named “Victorious [this month].” Japan’s “government by assassination” period ended with a failed coup on the 26th of this month. For 10 points, name this month whose 29th day saw fewer historical events, since it only happens every four years.
tossups.answer: February <History - European>
tossups.answer_formatted: February <History - European>

tossups.question: At the end of a short story originally written in this language, a mother weeps after answering her son’s question about why the title body parts have lighter palms. That story in this language, “The Hands of Blacks,” appears in the book, We Killed Mangy Dog. In a novel written in this language, the hunter Archangel “Archie” Bullseye is hired to kill the creatures preying on the women of Kulumani. Twenty-Fifth of June becomes a chicken after being confined to a hen house in another novel written in this language, which includes a subplot about the search for (*) Farida’s son Gaspar. Luis Bernardo Honwana wrote in this language, which another author used to write Confession of the Lioness and a book in which Muidinga and Tuahir discover the notebooks of Kindzu. Sleepwalking Land was written in―for 10 points―what European language used by Mia Couto and other authors from Mozambique?
tossups.answer: Portuguese [or Português] <Literature - Other/World>
tossups.answer_formatted: Portuguese <Literature - Other/World> [or Português]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. In allusion to its metaphorical “pillars,” this building’s floors hang off of four elevator-utility cores at the four corners. The underground concourse level of this building includes a skylit, circle-shaped water cascade called the “Contemplative Court.” A grassy greenroof covers the enormous Porch at this building’s south entrance. This building’s first and second floors are connected by an elliptical steel Monumental Staircase with no supports. A geometrical pattern perforates the bronze-colored aluminum (*) scrim surrounding this building. This building’s design alludes to a traditional “crown” shape, making its silhouette look like a stack of three inverted trapezoids. The Washington Monument stands just next to—for 10 points—what 2016 building by David Adjaye [“ADD”-jay], the newest Smithsonian museum?
tossups.answer: National Museum of African American History and Culture [or NMAAHC; accept any answer indicating the Smithsonian’s museum of African American or Black history and/or culture] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: National Museum of African American History and Culture <Arts - Audiovisual, Other> [or NMAAHC; accept any answer indicating the Smithsonian’s museum of African American or Black history and/or culture]
acceptable: National Museum of African American History and Culture <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
National Museum of African American History and Culture <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
any answer indicating the Smithsonian’s museum of African American

tossups.question: Cunha and Heckman argue that because skill formation technologies possess a type of complementarity described by this term, there are high returns to investing in early childhood development. This term describes the type of inefficiency resulting from capital overaccumulation in overlapping generations models. In games with this property, there may be Nash equilibria that all agents prefer but which are inconsistent without some sort of commitment device. (*) Stokey, Lucas, and Prescott wrote a textbook on models described by this term, drawing on methods invented by Richard Bellman. In those models described by this term, agents take as given a set of state variables and optimally choose an action that affects the future according to a transition probability or law of motion. This term precedes “stochastic general equilibrium” in a class of macroeconomic models often abbreviated as DSGE. For 10 points, name this term often contrasted with “static.”
tossups.answer: dynamic [accept dynamic complementarity, dynamic inefficiency, economic dynamics, dynamic programming, or dynamic stochastic general equilibrium]
tossups.answer_formatted: dynamic [accept dynamic complementarity, dynamic inefficiency, economic dynamics, dynamic programming, or dynamic stochastic general equilibrium]
acceptable: dynamic complementarity, dynamic inefficiency, economic dynamics, dynamic programming,

tossups.question: Examples of these substances associated with Cibicides and Cibicidoides have C13/C12 [C-13 to C-12] ratios that lag behind atmospheric levels and are used to track fluid parcels’ circulation. Transfer functions for comparing these substances use the prevalence of Emiliania huxleyi as a physical paleoproxy. The distribution of component size in these substances is bimodal and decreases over time as its larger component dissolves, resulting in a remainder of red clay. One type of them dominates the other in the Arctic, Antarctic, and the Equator due to the influx of nutrients from upwelling. Their diagenesis can result in the formation of (*) chert from discarded tests and, in other cases, begins with the needle-like isoform aragonite. These substances’ carbonaceous variety cannot form below the compensation depth and is primarily derived from coccolithophores, while their siliceous type is formed from diatoms. For 10 points, name these biogenous benthic sediments formed from 30% or more planktonic skeletons.
tossups.answer: oozes [accept siliceous ooze, diatomaceous ooze, carbonaceous ooze, coccolithophore ooze, or foraminiferal ooze; prompt on oceanic sediment or pelagic sediment; prompt on calcium carbonate, aragonite, or calcite; prompt on silica, or silicon dioxide] <Science - Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: oozes <Science - Other> [accept siliceous ooze, diatomaceous ooze, carbonaceous ooze, coccolithophore ooze, or foraminiferal ooze; prompt on oceanic sediment or pelagic sediment; prompt on calcium carbonate, aragonite, or calcite; prompt on silica, or silicon dioxide]
acceptable: siliceous ooze, diatomaceous ooze, carbonaceous ooze, coccolithophore ooze,

tossups.question: This government was founded on an island in a river outside of Bononia shortly after a man received words of caution in the dying breath of his adviser, Pansa. A major crisis for this government began with the expropriation of civilian land to resettle around 40,000 former soldiers, which led to a military standoff in Perusia. This government temporarily placated its last major opponent by giving him control of (*) Corsica, the Peloponnesus, Sardinia, and Sicily in the Pact of Misenum. The Treaty of Brundisium reset the arrangement between the power brokers of this government, which was plagued by the constant opposition of Sextus Pompeius. After this government was authorized by the Lex Titia, it immediately enacted proscriptions against Favonius, Lucius Julius Caesar, and Cicero. The Battle of Philippi was fought during the government of—for 10 points—what coalition of Lepidus, Antony, and Octavian?
tossups.answer: Second Triumvirate [prompt on Roman Republic or similar answers] <History - Mediterranean+>
tossups.answer_formatted: Second Triumvirate <History - Mediterranean+> [prompt on Roman Republic or similar answers]

tossups.question: Early modern scholars identified this man and his squire as the subject of a Giorgione painting in the Uffizi that more likely depicts Alexander the Great’s lieutenant Cleitus holding an ornate sword. A statue of this man is paired with two sets of relief sculptures, one of which quotes the Parthenon frieze and cannot be seen from any normal viewing angle. Gregorio di Allegretto made a pair of sarcophagi depicting this man in ancient armor and his son Gianantonio in modern armor for a tomb in il (*) Santo whose decoration was overseen by this man’s widow, Giacoma della Leonessa. Contrary to legend, this man wasn’t buried behind false doors in the 25-foot-high base of a bronze sculpture that depicts him wearing a breastplate bearing the winged head of Medusa. For 10 points, name this “honeyed cat,” a condottiero memorialized in an equestrian statue by Donatello.
tossups.answer: Gattamelata [or Erasmo di Narni; or Erasmo of Narni; accept Stefano di Narni; prompt on di Narni] <Arts - Visual>
tossups.answer_formatted: Gattamelata <Arts - Visual> [or Erasmo di Narni; or Erasmo of Narni; accept Stefano di Narni; prompt on di Narni]

tossups.question: Mau Mau veteran Ian Henderson was called the “butcher of” this country due to his long career as its director of state security which included resisting a mid-1990s uprising that helped force the National Action Charter of 2001. An athlete from this country was arrested and tortured for allegedly throwing Molotov cocktails at a police station, despite literally playing in a televised soccer match at the same time. Hakeem al-Araibi was nearly deported to this country while vacationing in Thailand, despite having been granted asylum by Australia. This country also jailed Sayed Adnan, who missed a penalty against New Zealand that could have qualified it for the (*) 2010 World Cup. Sheikh Salman, a native of this country, had his campaign for FIFA president derailed by this country’s “Bloody Thursday” crackdown on protestors in its Pearl Roundabout. For 10 points, name this island country ruled by the Khalifa family and connected by the King Fahd Causeway to Saudi Arabia, whose capital is Manama.
tossups.answer: Bahrain [or Kingdom of Bahrain] <Modern World>
tossups.answer_formatted: Bahrain <Modern World> [or Kingdom of Bahrain]

tossups.question: Despite being larger than this compound, carborane ligands called nido-dicarbollides have similar reactivity to it. A group of catalysts containing this ligand are made more efficient after reaction with methyl·alumin·oxane, forming a catalytic system named for Walter Kaminsky. Those catalysts, where two of this ligand are bound to titanium-group elements, are the second generation of homogeneous Ziegler–Natta catalysts. Two equivalents of this compound are joined by a linker group in compounds described by the prefix ansa. A manganese atom bonds to three carbonyl groups and a methylated form of compound to make an anti-knock agent. Titanium bonds to two equivalents of this compound and two bridging methyl groups in a carbonyl methylation reagent developed by (*) Fred Tebbe. Two equivalents of this compound have a hapticity of 5 when they bond to iron to form the sandwich compound ferrocene. For 10 points, name this cyclic hydrocarbon with formula C5H6.
tossups.answer: cyclopentadiene [accept cyclopentadienyl] <Science - Chemistry>
tossups.answer_formatted: cyclopentadiene <Science - Chemistry> [accept cyclopentadienyl]

tossups.question: This composer was discussed as one of three “apostles” of the central style in the final chapter of Daniel Heartz’s Music in European Capitals, which discusses his use of a double orchestra in his Opus 18 symphonies. Most of the music in this composer’s modern complete works edition was handwritten by editor Ernest Warburton, whose thematic catalogue gave rise to this composer’s “W.” numbers. This composer’s most famous large-scale work is probably a C-minor viola concerto that’s actually by Henri Casadesus [kah-zah-deh-ZYEW]. Three of this (*) Galant composer’s Opus 5 piano sonatas were arranged as the unnumbered piano concertos K. 107. This man co-founded a long-running concert series with the gamba player Carl Friedrich Abel in a city where he became the music master to George III’s wife. For 10 points, name this major influence on the young Mozart, who was known as the “London Bach.”
tossups.answer: Johann Christian Bach [accept just Johann Christian after “Bach”; prompt on partial answers like Johann Bach; accept The London Bach or The English Bach until “London”] <Arts - Auditory>
tossups.answer_formatted: Johann Christian Bach <Arts - Auditory> [accept just Johann Christian after “Bach; prompt on partial answers like Johann Bach; accept The London Bach or The English Bach until “London]

tossups.question: David Georgi translated a poem by this author in which the speaker threatens to pawn a prostitute’s clothes, until “that little Antichrist wheezes / and howls and swears by the death of Jesus / that I’ll do no such thing.” Each stanza of that poem by this author ends by referencing “the old whorehouse where” he and the title figure “hold court.” In Richard Wilbur’s translation of a different poem by this author, the speakers describe “the wind’s fantasy / Which has no object, yet would have us be / (Pitted like thimbles) at its beck and call” and the title (*) group as “rinsed and laundered by the rain.” This author of “The Ballad of Fat Margot” wrote a poem whose speaker asks “Where’s Hipparchia, and where is Thais” in a translation by Dante Gabriel Rossetti; that translation repeats the refrain “Where are the snows of yester-year?” For 10 points, name this medieval French author of Le Grand Testament, which contains his poem “The Ballad of Dead Ladies.”
tossups.answer: François Villon [vee-YAWN] <Literature - European>
tossups.answer_formatted: François Villon <Literature - European> [vee-YAWN]

tossups.question: On the Nixon tapes, this man is heard telling the president via phone call that “we got a little problem of identification as to how the people were killed,” an issue he shrugs off by saying “but that’s life.” After this man sent Clarence B. Jones to join William Kunstler and New York Times journalist Tom Wicker at the site of an unfolding crisis, Jones invoked this man’s secret donation of funds to bail Birmingham protesters out of jail to encourage this man to appear personally, as demanded by L. D. (*) Barkley. According to Heather Ann Thompson’s book Blood in the Water, this man led an extensive cover-up of his disastrous mismanagement after deploying 600 national guard members in the middle of September 1971 hostage negotiations. Harsh 1973 drug laws were enacted after the Attica riot was bungled by—for 10 points—what moderate Republican governor of New York who served as Gerald Ford’s Vice President, a member of a wealthy oil family?
tossups.answer: Nelson (Aldrich) Rockefeller <History - American>
tossups.answer_formatted: Nelson Rockefeller <History - American>

tossups.question: An influential definition of this broad doctrine was given in a 1980 book by a biographer of Jonathan Edwards named George Marsden. This doctrine received its name from a series of twelve pamphlets sponsored by Lyman Stewart. A conference dedicated to this doctrine was organized in 1919 by William Bell Riley. This doctrine was analyzed as an erroneous mixture of mythos and logos in a 2000 book by Karen Armstrong. Starting at the Niagara Conference, this doctrine became deeply linked with (*) dispensationalism. Many early adherents to this doctrine used the Scofield Reference Bible, imbibing its pre-millenarian commentary. A 2018 book groups Wheaton College and Bob Jones University as [This doctrine] U. This doctrine arose as a reaction to the Higher Criticism and other Modernist ideas. For 10 points, name this doctrine of interpreting the Bible literally.
tossups.answer: Christian fundamentalism [accept The Fundamentals; accept Fundamentalist U; prompt on conservatism, Creationism, evangelism, or Evangelical Christianity] <Religion>
tossups.answer_formatted: Christian fundamentalism <Religion> [accept The Fundamentals; accept Fundamentalist U; prompt on conservatism, Creationism, evangelism, or Evangelical Christianity]

tossups.question: A book section repeatedly expresses how watching this activity makes the narrator think of Zora Neale Hurston’s quote, “I feel most colored when I am thrown against a sharp white background.” An essay describes how its author succeeded at this activity through “geometric thinking” that accounted for the high winds of Central Illinois. The discrimination faced by a star of this profession is analyzed alongside the YouTuber Hennessy Youngman in the second chapter of Claudia Rankine’s “American Lyric,” (*) Citizen. A star of this profession was described as “Both Flesh and Not” by an author who may have made up a sequence celebrating one of that star’s namesake “Moments.” This activity is the subject of the essay “Derivative Sport in Tornado Alley” and John McPhee’s Levels of the Game. For 10 points, name this favorite subject of David Foster Wallace, who wrote an essay about the “religious experience” of seeing it being played by Roger Federer.
tossups.answer: playing tennis <Literature - American>
tossups.answer_formatted: playing tennis <Literature - American>

tossups.question: David Lyon analyzed how religion has transformed in postmodern society in a book titled Jesus in [this place]. Louis Marin put forth this place as the foremost example of a “degenerate utopia.” A book claims that the “objective profile of the United States, then, may be traced” through this place, which the author compares to the Watergate scandal. An essay about this non-Asian location is criticized in Rem Koolhaas’s S,M,L,XL for making the imperialist assumption that only Westerners can embrace modernity. That essay titled for this place contrasts the perfect cleanness of supermalls with the (*) execution of Dutchman Johannes van Damme. This place is called the “quintessence of consumer ideology” and described as embodying the title quality even more than nearby Hearst Castle in Umberto Eco’s “Travels in Hyperreality.” William Gibson described Singapore as “[this location] with the Death Penalty.” For 10 points, name this popular California theme park where children can be accosted by men dressed as 6-foot rodents.
tossups.answer: Disneyland [do not accept or prompt on “Disneyworld”] <Mythology and Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: Disneyland <Mythology and Other> [do not accept or prompt on "Disneyworld"]

tossups.question: A formula to compute this concept’s “breath” calculates the Bhattacharya distance between the distribution of resources and the population distribution. Its “breath” can also be calculated by summing one over the sum of squares of proportions of individuals in each “resource state” in a uniformity measure developed by Richard Levins. When this concept is repeatedly (*) “pre-empted,” the relative abundance distribution takes the form of a geometric series. Robert MacArthur analogized its apportionment to randomly breaking a stick into pieces. George Hutchinson defined these concepts as n-dimensional hypervolumes in a space whose dimensions are environmental factors. Because they will overlap in the presence of competition, organisms occupy their “realized” type rather than their “fundamental” type. Interspecific competition occurs when these domains overlap. For 10 points, name this ecological concept, the location and role of a given species within a community.
tossups.answer: ecological niches <Science - Biology>  Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by haha tfw u neg (Sam Bailey, Rahul Keyal, Matthew Lehmann, Kevin Wang) and Now somewhere in the Black Mountain Hills of Dakota there lived some olds named BHSU (Billy Busse, Rob Carson, Andrew Hart, Tejas Raje)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: One component of this phenomenon occurs via long-term potentiation and long-term depression. For 10 points each:
answers: NMDA receptors [or N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors] and AMPA receptors [or α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors]
Arc [or activity-regulated cytoskeleton associated protein] <Science - Biology>
parts: Name this generic term which refers to the brain’s ability to permanently change and reorganize itself, frequently via the strengthening and weakening of synapses.

Synaptic plasticity is largely regulated by the activity of these two types of ion channels. Along with the kainate receptor, these two receptors allow the neurotransmitter glutamate to alter the balance of cations inside and outside of nerve cells. Name both.

This plasticity protein in the “immediate early gene” family serves as a regulator of synaptic strength. Its generic-sounding name references the dependency of its localization to the synapse on microtubule-associated transport and actin-dependent docking.
answers_formatted: NMDA receptors and AMPA receptors [or α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors] [or N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors]
acceptable: NMDA receptors and AMPA receptors [or α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors]
NMDA receptors and AMPA receptors [or α-amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid receptors]

bonuses.leadin: This man’s major project was heavily informed by the work of biochemist Lu Gwei-djen, whom he married. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this chemist and historian. In his many-volume history of science in China, this man asked why China fell behind Europe despite an early technological advantage, his namesake “question.”

Mark Elvin’s answer to the Needham Question in part cites a shift in elite culture from Daoism to this other Chinese belief system. Chinese civil servants took torturous exams that forced them to recite passages from this system’s Five Classics.
This University of Chicago historian sought to synthesize ecological, geographic, and economic causes to explain the Needham question in his seminal work, The Great Divergence.

bonuses.leadin: After being shown this creature by Cico, the narrator is awestruck by it and considers it a pagan god. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this golden-colored creature. The narrator, Antonio, begins to turn away from Catholicism after Samuel tells him a myth about it.
Antonio learns about the golden carp in this 1972 Rudolfo Anaya novel, in which he is mentored by the title elderly healer.

Throughout the novel, Antonio is comforted by this animal, which is spiritually linked to Ultima and dies when she dies. While protecting Ultima from an attack, it savagely gouges out one of Tenorio’s eyes.

bonuses.leadin: This policy was supported by the Bureau of Shrines and is generally held to differ from a “Sect” variant. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this two-word English-language term for an unofficial policy that was banned by a 1945 directive, which held that this practice contributed to nationalism and militarism during World War II.

This intellectual movement, whose name means “native studies,” began during the Tokugawa period as an attempt to remove Chinese influences from traditional Japanese religion. Moto·ori Norinaga contributed to this movement with his complete analysis of the Kojiki.

Though freedom of religion is enshrined in Japan’s postwar constitution, politicians like Junichirō Koizumi have made visits to this Shinto shrine that honors Japan’s war dead, including many convicted war criminals.

bonuses.leadin: A book on “picturing” this man reprinted his “Lecture on Pictures,” which argued that photography allowed anyone to make their “subjective nature objective,” even in spite of a prejudiced documenter. For 10 points each:
answers: Frederick Douglass [or Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey]
parts: Name this man who also gave lectures titled “Age of Pictures,” “Life Pictures,” and “Pictures and Progress.” Many photographs of him were preserved in albums collected by Arabella Chapman.

Frederick Douglass, who’s done an amazing job and is being recognized more and more, saw photography as a counterpoint to minstrelsy, which he denounced often in essays for this newspaper that he edited from 1847 to 1851.
Douglass invoked the example of white viewers confronting a photograph of this Mississippi senator, the first African American to serve in either house of Congress.

bonuses.leadin: Gustav Mahler named his first symphony after this author’s novel Titan. For 10 points each:
answers: Jean Paul [or Johann Paul Friedrich Richter; or Jean Paul Richter]
parts: Name this early German Romantic novelist who used a French pseudonym. The twins Walt and Vult in his unfinished novel The Awkward Age inspired Robert Schumann’s personas Florestan and Eusebius.
Critics like Friedrich Schlegel often compared Jean Paul’s digressive novels to the books of this Irish-born author, who became a European celebrity after writing Tristram Shandy.

This German author loved Sterne, and considered him equal to Shakespeare. A blistering polemic by Karl Kraus blames this man for infecting German literature with the “feuilleton” [foy-TAWN] after his 1831 flight from Germany to Paris.
answers_formatted: Jean Paul [or Johann Paul Friedrich Richter; or Jean Paul Richter]

bonuses.leadin: This man recorded Miles Davis’s albums Workin’ and Steamin’ in the living room of his own parents’ house. For 10 points each:
answers: Etta [accept Jamesetta, which was Etta James’s real first name]
parts: Name this man who helped create the “Blue Note Sound” at his namesake Studio in New Jersey. A remaster series called his namesake “edition” includes albums like Blue Train and Somethin’ Else.

Van Gelder recorded Don’t Go to Strangers and many other albums for a singer with this first name and surname Jones. A jazz and soul singer with this first name recorded the song “At Last” for Chess Records.

In 1957, Van Gelder became one of the first to embrace this recording technology, which required the use of two-track tape. This technology was finally adopted fully by the Beatles in 1968 for the White Album.
answers_formatted: Etta [accept Jamesetta, which was Etta James’s real first name]
acceptable: Jamesetta, which was Etta James’s real first name

bonuses.leadin: Probes like TaqMan use this phenomenon to monitor the progress of PCR in real-time. For 10 points each:
answers: iso·thio·cyanate [or ITC; accept FITC; accept phenyl iso·thio·cyanate; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name this phenomenon that underlies dyes like rhodamine and SYBR Green. Osamu Shimomura purified a protein which displays this phenomenon, allowing it to be used as a reporter for gene expression.

The dye fluorescein is frequently derivatized with this functional group, which is responsible for the pungency of wasabi and horseradish. When benzene is substituted with this functional group, it forms a reagent used to sequence proteins in the Edman degradation.

These probes for qPCR consist of a synthetic hairpin-shaped oligonucleotide with a fluorophore at the 5-prime end and a quencher at the 3-prime end. When they bind to a target sequence, they unfold, moving the quencher away from the fluorophore.
answers_formatted: iso·thio·cyanate [or ITC; accept FITC; accept phenyl iso·thio·cyanate; do not accept or prompt on "partial answers"]

bonuses.leadin: A city founded by this man on Huelen Hill was later heroically defended by his mistress, Ines de Suarez, against near-total annihilation by Michima Lonco. For 10 points each:
answers: Mapuche [or, I suppose, the Araucanians if you’re an EVIL IMPERIALIST]
parts: Name this man whose heart, according to an epic poem by Alonso de Ercilla, was removed and passed around like a hot potato on the orders of Caupolicán, one of several toqui chiefs this man battled.

Pedro de Valdivia supposedly cut the toes off of an invading force of these people at El Valle de la Mocha, where they were led by Lautaro. These winners at the Battle of Tucapel retained independence to the Bio Bio river throughout the entire colonial era.
Before his heart problems, Pedro de Valdivia served as a lieutenant under this man, who executed his most famous foe after capturing him at Cajamarca.
answers_formatted: Mapuche [or or, I suppose, the Araucanians if you’re an EVIL IMPERIALIST]
acceptable: or, I suppose, the Araucanians if you’re an EVIL IMPERIALIST

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. The sketch that became this work was doodled in about an hour on a piece of discarded newspaper, after which the artist suggested centering it on the top of the product so that it could be seen more easily. For 10 points each:

parts: Identify this piece of commercial art produced at the request of the Catalan candy magnate Enric Bernat. It consists of a yellow, eight-petaled daisy outline surrounding two cursive words in red.
This artist designed the Chupa Chups logo in 1969, 15 years after he painted The Disintegration of his own painting The Persistence of Memory.
This Franco-American “Father of Industrial Design” created classic logos for Hoover, Exxon, Shell, and Nabisco, among many others.

bonuses.leadin: Both this standard and the earlier asm.js can be generated using the Emscripten SDK. For 10 points each:
answers: WebAssembly [or Wasm; do not accept or prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this open standard for frontend development that allows browser applications to be compiled into a more efficient binary encoding. It was first released as a minimum viable product in 2017.

Like its namesake, WebAssembly uses an architecture based on “sets” of these statements, allowing execution by an in-browser virtual machine. Interpreters convert program statements to these statements in machine code.

WebAssembly’s support for LLVM languages makes it viable for use with this language, the “most loved” by Stack Overflow users every year since 2016. This language invented by Mozilla borrows traits from Haskell and uses the keywords match and let, but it’s perhaps best known for its property of “fearless concurrency.”
answers_formatted: WebAssembly [or Wasm; do not accept or prompt on partial answer]

bonuses.leadin: A claim about this event originated in the Annals of the Empire discussing the reign of Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian II. For 10 points each:
answers: Suleiman the Magnificent [or Suleiman I; or Kanuni Sultan Suleyman; or Soliman]
parts: Voltaire claimed that “nothing is better known” than what event, where the great commander Dragut was killed by a cannonball while trying to cut off Fort St. Elmo from Fort St. Angelo?
Voltaire’s original quote goes on to claim that the siege checked the fortunes of this Ottoman sultan, whose forces besieged Vienna in 1527.

The siege was resisted by the Knights Hospitaller, an order originally founded by a “blessed” Benedictine with this name. This is also the surname of a man who had his skin slowly pincered off as punishment for a murder committed while the victim was talking to Welsh commander Roger Williams.
answers_formatted: Suleiman the Magnificent [or Suleiman I; or Kanuni Sultan Suleyman; or Soliman]

bonuses.leadin: This man’s father of the same name was the first to introduce the symbol for pi. For 10 points each:
answers: hospitality [or hospes; accept Of Hospitality] <Social Science>
parts: Name this orientalist scholar, who, in 1786 posited connections between Sanskrit and western languages such as Latin, which developed into the theory of Proto-Indo-European.

Languages of the Indo-European family are divided into two groups largely based on their pronunciation of the word with this meaning, based on whether the initial consonant merged with the plain velar.

Emile Beneveniste’s work on the shared Indo-European roots of the words for “hostility” and this other word for the practice of receiving a guest with goodwill, influenced a 2000 book by Jacques Derrida.

bonuses.leadin: This director screamed at an actress to “Hit her! Hit her again!” during the hour-long filming of a fight scene, and he threw a monitor into the street after his leads giggled during the 100th take of their meet-cute. For 10 points each:
answers: male gaze [do not accept or prompt on putative synonyms]
parts: Name this Tunisian-French filmmaker, who became the first director to win a Palme d’Or alongside his lead actors for 2013’s Blue Is the Warmest Colour, starring Adèle Exarchopoulos and Léa Seydoux.

The long, gratuitous sex scenes in Kechiche’s films have been deemed exemplars of this two-word term. Laura Mulvey’s “Visual Pleasure and Narrative Cinema” coined this term for the scopophilic depiction of women by men.
The most recent instalment of Kechiche’s Mektoub, My Love trilogy has this subtitle. Ingrid Bergman’s Hollywood debut was as a violinist’s lover in a 1939 David O. Selznick film with this title.
answers_formatted: male gaze [do not accept or prompt on "putative synonyms"]

bonuses.leadin: This critic contrasted Chaucer and Pope’s use of rhyme in his essay “On the Relation of Rhyme to Reason.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this proponent of New Criticism, who collected his essays in books like Hateful Contraries and The Verbal Icon.

Wimsatt collaborated with Monroe Beardsley to write essays arguing that these two critical fallacies result in “biography and relativism.” They defined one of them as “a confusion between the poem and its results,” and the other as “a confusion between the poem and its origins.”

Another New Critic, Cleanth Brooks, analyzed this author’s poem “The Canonization” in his essay “The Well-Wrought Urn.” T.S. Eliot’s essay “The Metaphysical Poets” praises this author’s “unified sensibility” of thought and feeling.

bonuses.leadin: In the eighteenth century, emphasis placed on clinical practice and physiology led this city to surpass Padua as a center of medical learning. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this city where modern medical instruction was pioneered by Herman Boerhaave. This institution’s famed Hortus Botanicus was located next to an observatory built to house Rudolph Snellius’s great quadrant.

Leiden was home to one of Europe’s first “theaters” for observing this practice central to empirical anatomical learning. Nicolaes Tulp, who was instructed at Leiden, was painted carrying out this type of instruction by Rembrandt.

Boerhaave was the teacher of this man, who revolutionized medicine in the Habsburg empire while serving as Maria Theresa’s personal doctor. To his considerable aggravation, this man was dispatched to solve a local vampire problem in Serbia after the Treaty of Passarowitz brought Balkan lands into the Habsburg domain.

bonuses.leadin: This school of philosophy was developed during a so-called “period of cessation” and was influenced by gnostic and Sufi beliefs. For 10 points each:
answers: Mulla Sadra [or Sadr ad-Dīn Muhammad Shīrāzī] <Philosophy>
parts: Name this mystical school of Islamic philosophy founded by the twelfth-century Persian thinker Suhrawardi. It is based on the principle of sufficient reason and the Aristotelian injunction against actual infinities.
Suhrawardi translated this philosopher’s work Treatise of the Bird into Persian, although he opposed this man’s Peripatetic views. This man also wrote an encyclopedia called the Canon of Medicine.
This seventeenth-century Persian philosopher, considered the master of illuminationist philosophy, described a doctrine of existence in his best-known work, Four Journeys.

bonuses.leadin: Barack Obama’s Justice Department developed a legal theory involving “associated forces” to argue that this document justified targeting ISIS. For 10 points each:
answers: AUMF [or Authorization for (the) Use of Military Force (Against Terrorists)]
Hamdan v. Rumsfeld [prompt on Rumsfeld; do not accept “Hamdi,” which is a different case] <Modern World>
parts: Essentially the entire War on Terror has been justified through a 2001 example of what sort of Congressional resolution, the only way the President can exceed the limits of the War Powers Resolution without a formal declaration of war?
The only member of Congress to vote against the AUMF, Barbara Lee, continues to represent this state in the House of Representatives. Nancy Pelosi also represents this state.

The Supreme Court held that the language of the AUMF did not authorize the President to convene military tribunals in contravention of the Geneva Accords and the Uniform Code of Military Justice in this 2006 case. It was brought by a Yemeni bodyguard of Osama bin Laden.
answers_formatted: AUMF [or Authorization for (the) Use of Military Force (Against Terrorists)]
Hamdan v. Rumsfeld <Modern World> [prompt on Rumsfeld; do not accept "Hamdi,” which is a different case"]

bonuses.leadin: The dispersion relation for these entities is approximately linear in the low-wavenumber limit and always has a frequency value lower than that of a related branch. For 10 points each:
answers: boundary of the first Brillouin zone [accept edge of the first Brillouin zone; do not accept or prompt on partial answers]
parts: Name these vibrational modes, which are in-phase displacements of atoms in a crystal lattice.
At this point, the frequency of an acoustic phonon reaches a maximum value of 2 times the square root of the spring constant divided by mass.

The resistivity of metals is linear in this quantity, due to the interaction between electrons and phonons. In the denominator of the exponential term of the Arrhenius equation, the gas constant R multiplies this intensive quantity, measured in Kelvin.

bonuses.leadin: The first play written by a person with this ethnicity, The Cherry Pickers, was smuggled out of jail on sheets of toilet paper. For 10 points each:
answers: Miles Franklin [or Stella Maria Sarah Miles Franklin] <Literature - Other/World>
parts: Name this ethnicity of the activist author Kevin Gilbert. An author with this ethnicity, who changed her name from Kath Walker, described a “semi-naked band subdued and silent” who feel like strangers in a “little town” in her poem “We are Going.”
This author controversially depicted a murder spree by an indigenous Australian in his novel The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith. He won the Booker Prize for his novel Schindler’s Ark.
In 2007, the second novel by indigenous Australian author Alexis Wright, Carpentaria, won the most prestigious Australian literary award, which is named for this author of My Brilliant Career.
answers_formatted: Miles Franklin <Literature - Other/World> [or Stella Maria Sarah Miles Franklin]
